text: hello and welcome everyone this is active inference guest stream number 55.1 it's august 30th 2023 today we are going to have a presentation followed by a discussion on geometric constraints on human brain function by james pang and alex fornito thank you again for joining really looking forward to the presentation and the discussion so please off to youtube to introduce yourself and continue however you like thank you
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Well, thanks very much, Daniel.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: My name is Alex Fornita.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I'm based in the School of Psychological Sciences and the Turner Institute for Brain and Mental Health at Monash University.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And I'm here with James Penn, who is a research fellow working in the team.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so the idea today was that we were going to talk a little bit about this work.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I'll begin by providing a bit of a historical and theoretical background, and then James will
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: take over and jump into the specifics of what we did and what we found.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We're assuming some basic understanding of neuroscience and some elements of human brain imaging and we'll go through a little bit of maths but hopefully it'll be enough to give a picture and if there's any questions about it afterwards we'll be happy to try and answer them.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So a key motivating factor for this work is really trying to understand how the structure or anatomy of the brain constrains its function.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And if you look at a diverse range of systems found throughout nature, we know that the structure of the system constrains its dynamics.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So for example, the shape of a racing car will influence its aerodynamics and how fast it can go.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: folding patterns of a protein will influence the other proteins that it can interact with and have quite large effects.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So here, for example, we've got an example of the hemoglobin protein in a healthy person and someone with sickle cell anemia.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this change in the geometry of the protein leads to a 20 year difference in life expectancy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And here we've got the molecular structures of diamond and graphite.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So both of these
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: materials are made of the same atoms.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They're all purely carbon atoms.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's just the bonds between them that are different.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that difference is sufficient to create quite a variation in the properties of the material.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So diamond being one of the hardest substances on earth and valued at somewhere between 12 to $90 million per kilo.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: whereas graphite is one of the most brittle and only cost you about $20 per kilo.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so this is essentially the reason why we don't propose to people with a H2B pencil, we use diamond rings instead.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now, the brain is no different.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We think anatomy constraints function, but there has been a longstanding debate about the specific properties that are the most relevant and how we should best conceptualize them.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this can be traced back to
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The days of Ramani Kahal and Kamila Golgi, two people considered to be some of the founding fathers of modern neuroscience.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Golgi developed a technique for staining neurons that allowed you to visualize their structure under the microscope.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And Kahal really perfected that technique and studied the nervous system in extensive detail and really laid down the foundations for what we think about the anatomy of the brain to this day.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now, both of these men were recognized for their efforts in 1906 with a Nobel Prize.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But even at the award ceremony, when giving their lectures, they were in bitter disagreement.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So if you actually look at the recordings of their lectures, Cahal says, we applied Golgi's method and our observations revealed, in my opinion, the terminal arrangement of the nerve fibers.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Nerve elements possess reciprocal relationships in contiguity, but not in continuity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So here he's saying that cells are fundamentally discrete elements separated in physical space and that there's a gap between them at the synapse, the synaptic cleft, and signaling occurs through this gap.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Golgi, on the other hand, didn't agree.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: He said, while I admire the brilliancy of the doctrine, which is a worthy product of the high intellect of my illustrious Spanish colleague,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I cannot agree with him on some points of an anatomical nature which are for the theory of fundamental importance.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I found myself unable to follow the current of opinion because I was confronted by one concrete anatomical fact.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This was the existence of the formation which I have called the diffuse nerve network.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so for Golgi, all the cells were continuous.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They form one continuous network.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There was no
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: point of separation between them and signaling occurred through this continuous network.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now, ultimately, a growing body of evidence, and you can see it in Golgi's statements, was starting to favor Cahal's model,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But really it was only resolved in the 1940s with the advent of electron microscopy where people could actually resolve synapses and saw that they were spatially disjoint.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this ultimately established the neuron doctrine as the fundamental theory about how the nervous system is organized at a cellular level.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this basic idea that we can divide the brain up into discrete units was then carried through to different scales, most famously by Corbinian-Brodman, who developed a parcellation of the cortex based on cytoarchitectonic grounds.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: His idea was that different parts of the cortex have different cellular properties, and so they define these discrete areas that are functionally specialised in some way.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And certainly this has been a very influential idea in neuroscience ever since.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But around the same time, in fact, a couple of years earlier, the neurologist Alfred Campbell published his own cytoarchitectonic map.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And he agreed that you could identify discrete boundaries largely in primary zones, but then in the cortex in between, it was a lot more difficult to find sharp outlines or boundaries.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And he suggested that actually the changes were more gradual or continuous in nature.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Brodmann's view became more popular and certainly became sort of the dominant theory in neuroscience, even though subsequent attempts to try to replicate it were different.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so different anatomists would parcellate the brain in different ways, using different boundaries and so on.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But nonetheless, this kind of...
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: congruence between the discrete model of Cajal and the discrete model of Brodmann eventually led to the idea that you know essentially we can think about the brain as a multi-scale network where at the cellular level we can identify discrete cells that are connected by synapses then we can scale up at the population level at a mesoscale resolution and identify how population of cells are linked by
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: bundles of axons.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then all the way through to the macro scales, which is what you sort of see when you look at one of Brodmann's maps, you have these broad, roughly pseudo-architectonic areas connected by white matter bundles.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And in the last two or so decades, we've had the
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: measurement techniques for characterizing these networks on a vast scale and there's been a pretty well established pipeline for mapping these networks.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the basic idea is that we have the brain, we divide it up into these discrete areas and they act as our network nodes and then for every pair of nodes we measure some aspect of structural or functional connectivity between them, functional connectivity being some aspect of coupling and activity,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then we can represent that in the form of a connectivity matrix.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So each row and column represents a different region.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And each element tells you about the type and strength of connectivity between areas that can equivalently be represented as a graph.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then with that graph representation, we can apply all sorts of different analytic tools to understand different aspects about how the network is connected and organized.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this basic approach has been used quite extensively to understand how the underlying anatomical properties of the network constrain function.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is one of my favorite examples.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This was a study of two different worms, C. elegans and P. pacificus.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Both of their nervous systems in the head have been mapped at the level of each cell and synapse.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And they're actually identical.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So they've got the same
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: type of cells, the same number of cells.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's just the connectivity between them that's different.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that's what you see in this network projection here, that the topology of the network's different.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And in this study, they showed that changes in the connectivity of just two hub neurons were sufficient to elicit a difference in the behavior of the animals such that P. pacificus is a predator of C. elegans.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And here you can see Pacificus eating poor C. elegans for lunch.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now, we can't lock humans up in a room and see who eats who and try to understand how their anatomy constraints function in that way.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But we can do things like use MRI to measure anatomical connectivity and functional connectivity and correlate the two.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that's pretty consistent finding that we generally find there is a correlation between them.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We can run computational models where we have a structural network, we simulate the activity, then we apply, say, a lesion to that network and look at the effects on the activity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we can show, for example, that if you lesion a hub area, you have quite a dramatic impact on brain function compared to if you lesion a more weakly connected non-hub area.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Or we could use clinical studies.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We could look at cases where there are naturally arising lesions through stroke or some other form of brain damage.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and we can understand the functional impairments that result.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So for example, in this case, people with lesions to certain types of hub areas with diffuse connectivity showed much more generalized cognitive impairments than people with lesions to areas with more specific patterns of connectivity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So this is great.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This has been really informative and great for understanding the role of individual brain regions or connections in brain function.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But it doesn't really give us a coherent, unified perspective about how dynamics emerge from the underlying structure.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's all a little bit piecemeal.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If we want to develop such a coherent understanding, we can draw some inspiration from different
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: of physics and engineering, where typically the structural constraints on the dynamics of a system are studied by understanding the eigenmodes of the system.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now the eigenvalues of a system are found by solving an eigenvalue problem such as this one.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So an eigenvector we can think of as something that we measure about a system that doesn't change its direction if it's subjected to some kind of transformation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So if that's the case, then this equality holds.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the idea here is that psi is our vector, something we measure about the system, subjected to some transformation L,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And if psi is an eigenvector, then the transformed eigenvector is equal to the eigenvector just scaled by some value.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the transformation can scale the vector, but it doesn't change its direction.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so if that's the case, then this scaling factor lambda is what we call an eigenvalue and psi is an eigenvector.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This kind of equation is applied to a lot of different systems, a lot of different contexts.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But when we're studying the eigenmodes of a system, typically our L term here is an operator called the Laplacian operator, which essentially describes how smoothly some kind of structural property of the system varies through an appropriate spatial embedding.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I'll come back a little bit to what that means, because we can make different choices for what we use in L, and that determines the specific anatomical properties that we prioritize.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But for now, I just want to emphasize that a key property of these eigenvectors is that they're orthogonal.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so then we can use them as a basis set for reconstructing different activity patterns that we might see in the network.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I guess the most famous example of a basis set that many people will be familiar with is a Fourier set.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So, for example, here we have some one dimensional signal and we can decompose that signal as a weighted sum of sine and cosine functions of varying frequencies.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So here you've got the different functions, different frequencies, and here you've got some weighting factors and we can reconstruct this signal as a weighted sum of these functions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In a similar way, we can extract our eigenmodes of the brain.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: based on some particular anatomical property.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we end up with these spatial patterns here that are organized, again, in terms of spatial frequency or the wavelength of fluctuation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So here you can see you've got a very low frequency fluctuation moving from back to front, top to bottom, medial, lateral.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then as you move up, you get these more high frequency fluctuations.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so then we can use these patterns to reconstruct any spatial map that we observe on the brain.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So it could be a map of brain activity recorded during a particular task.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It could be, say, a map of cortical thickness variations or gray matter volume variations.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's sufficiently general to allow you to reconstruct any type of map.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so we can do that just as a weighted sum.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So here Y represents our map, and then we represent that as a weighted sum of our modes with the A coefficients representing the weights.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And people, oh, sorry, I should emphasize that that explanation can be a little bit abstract for people who aren't familiar with Eigenmodes, and it is always a bit of a challenge to get an intuition.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so you can do what one of the people in the team did and ask ChatGPT to explain Eigenmodes to a 10-year-old, and it turns out that it does a pretty good job.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I was quite happy with this explanation, so I thought I'd share it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So ChatGPT says, of course, let's imagine we have a wobbly, jiggly ball of jelly.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: when you poke it, it wiggles and shakes, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now imagine if you poke the jelly in different spots or with different amounts of force.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Each time you poke it differently, the jelly wiggles and shakes in a different way.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Eigen modes are like those different ways the jelly wiggles and shakes when you poke it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So essentially seeing this video here, the jelly is poked and it wobbles in a particular way.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If you poke the jelly in a different spot or with a different amount of force, you'll trigger a different pattern of vibration.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so commonly, eigenmodes are used in the context of systems that vibrate.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the idea is these eigenmodes correspond to preferred patterns of vibration when the system is perturbed.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And those preferred patterns are just dictated by the structural properties of that system.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We can extend it more generally and think about it more as how a system responds to any type of excitation and how an excitation spreads through some connected system.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the eigenmodes correspond to the preferred patterns of excitation, again, determined by the physical properties of the system.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So naturally, given everything we've been talking about and these ideas that the brain is a multi-scale network, we need to make a choice about
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: how we define alloplastia and what specific anatomical properties are we going to extract our eigenmodes from.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so a natural choice would be to extract them from brain connectivity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we can do this quite in a reasonably straightforward way.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We get some map of the connections in the brain.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We map connectivity between every pair of nodes after we
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: apply some discretization.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We define our discrete nodes.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We map every pair of connections.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We represent that in the form of a matrix.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then we extract this quantity here.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's called a graph Laplacian.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The details are not so important, but that's essentially our L operator here.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And it describes how smoothly connectivity varies as we move from node to node in the network.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And when we do that, several studies have shown that you can use the eigenmodes extracted from this graphyloplasm to reconstruct kind of classic functional networks that you record with functional MRI.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We can reconstruct different patterns of functional connectivity between pairs of areas.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You can use it to reconstruct different EEG signals.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And people have even shown that you can make predictions about the pattern of neurodegeneration
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: that you see in different forms of dementia.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So this has been really fantastic, important work and a really important proof of principle that this Eigenmode framework can be used to understand how the structure of the system constrains its dynamics.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And in each case, the interpretation is that these dynamical patterns that we see with fMRI or EEG or so on,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This view very much aligns with what we would think of as a classical view of brain organisation that I've just been discussing.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So following from Cahal and Brodmann's work, the idea is that at lots of different scales, we can divide the brain up into discrete areas, they're connected in some way, and it's the signalling along these connections between these discrete areas that
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: drives activity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But there are reasons to think that particularly at a coarser scale, so we know at the fundamental cellular scale, the network is discrete, but at coarser scales, perhaps a different set of approximations might be useful.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

speaker: SPEAKER_00

speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And as we've talked about, there's been a lot of debate about where you can actually draw boundaries between discrete areas and how valid and reliable that is outside some kind of classic examples, say, in primary cortex.

speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You see you get these deep penetrating fibres that are coming in from the white matter.

speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But you can also see that there's a lot of connectivity
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: that's moving horizontally or tangential to the geometry of the cortex.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so these horizontal connections allow for the continuous spread of activity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So rather than activity jumping between discrete nodes, it can actually spread as a propagating wave.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And just to emphasize some of the limitations of the discrete model,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Not long after Brodmann's work, just a couple of decades, the renowned physiologist, Lorente Deneau, was pretty emphatic about his concerns with the approach.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: He said, the only really good cytoarchitectonic pictures are those of Campbell, who let me put in capital letters, as being the only cytoarchitectonist who has described facts and only facts.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The German cytoarchitectonist has mixed facts and theory in such a manner that nobody can tell where facts ends and theories begin.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Again, this is just emphasizing the idea that while we might be able to define discrete areas that are mesoscopic or macroscopic resolutions in some cases, especially around the borders of primary sensory or motor areas, for large swathes of cortex, those distinctions become a little bit blurry.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So an alternative approach has emerged out of neural field theory.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So neural field theory has been around for several decades now.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this is a different approach to thinking about cortical activity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the basic idea is that instead of dividing the brain into discrete specialised areas or nodes, we can treat the cortex as a continuous sheet.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we're actually interested in trying to capture
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: how patterns of brain activity propagate through that continuous shape.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so this is something that you can see in diverse types of electrophysiological recordings.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So this, for example, this video is of the dynamics of voltage-sensitive dyes recorded in the mouse brain.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And you can see that you observe these propagating waves of excitation that move continuously through the cortex, rather than jumping from region to region, as would be implied by a kind of
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: strongly discrete model.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So a big emphasis in neural field theory is on describing these wave-like propagation patterns.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And it's been shown in recent theoretical work that if we accept that wave-like propagation drives neuronal activity, then really the eigenmodes that we should be extracting or prioritizing are those that are derived from the geometry of the brain.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So our eigenvalue becomes this problem here, where this operator here is called the Laplace-Beltrami operator, and it describes how smoothly the geometry or the shape or the curvature of the brain varies through space.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And just to briefly explain why that's the case, here we've got the wave equation that's used in some forms of neural field theory, at least the versions that we've been focusing on.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so the basic idea is that the
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: firing rate of a given population of neurons B at location R and T is given by the afferent field of incoming population.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So other populations A. So we've got other populations providing this afferent field of activity that determines the firing rate of B.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And obviously we then need to describe what this afferent field looks like.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that's given by this part of the equation here.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So on the left here, this set of terms describes how the field evolves through time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We're not going to focus on that today.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Over here, which is what we're interested in, where we've got how the field is evolving through space.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so here we can see our friend, the Laplace-Beltrami operator, which describes the geometry.

text: And here we've got the length scale of axonal connectivity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So in this model, we make a very simple assumption about connectivity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We assume each point is connected to its neighbours in a distance-dependent and isotropic way.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that distance dependence is roughly exponential.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the idea is that areas nearby to a given location R will have a strong influence
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that influence declines roughly exponentially as a function of distance.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the speed of that decay is given by this R term here.

text: You can see that geometry is firmly embedded in this equation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now, I should point out this isn't something that's just been plucked out of thin air.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is a damped wave equation that has been used for centuries to describe wave dynamics in all sorts of different media.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so from that,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: we know very well that the geometry of the system constrains the spatial properties of wave propagation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And you can start from first principles of neuronal biophysics and derive this equation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And given all that work, we know that the eigenmodes of the Laplace Beltrami operator actually correspond to the standing waves of the dynamics.

text: So what are standing waves?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So in this simple example, we've got two traveling waves here, a blue and a green.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And as they interact with each other, you get these patterns of constructive and destructive interference represented by this red line here that cause these very large amplitude fluctuations that are fixed in space.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So they're not actually traveling like the original carrier waves.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They're fixed in space.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So that's why they're called standing waves.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And they're a nice example of resonance.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So these fluctuations in the red trace are much larger in amplitude than the original carrier waves.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So it's an example of resonance where we're getting a larger response in the system than the energy that we put in.

speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is a little bit gratuitous, but you can extend the idea to three dimensions and you can actually cause the particles to levitate.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Again, in this case,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: they're trapped within the nodal lines of sound waves that are being projected in three dimensions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this does have real world consequences.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So this is a video of the Tacoma Narrows Bridge in the 1940s.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The engineers didn't pay enough attention to eigenmodes and so
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: on this particular day, crosswinds hit the bridge in just the right spots and at just the right frequencies to excite the eigenmodes of the bridge.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So you trigger these resonant responses and create these large scale amplitude fluctuations that ultimately led to the collapse of the bridge.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So hopefully that background has kind of illustrated that there's sort of two different views of thinking about
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: which anatomical properties of the brain might be more important in constraining dynamics.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So on the one hand, we have the classical kind of connectome-centric view in which we view the cortex as comprising discrete areas, and dynamics are dominated by node-to-node transmission.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The connectivity between areas is topologically complex and not homogeneous, and we very much think that that's very important, and so we prioritize measuring that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We don't really directly account for the spatial embedding of the network or its geometry.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We can look at it secondarily, but it's not baked into the model.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And because we're interested in connectivity, that means we need to measure it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So from a practical perspective, at least if you're dealing with mirror imaging data, you need a T1 weighted image to measure brain anatomy, but also diffusion MRI image to be able to measure brain connectivity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The other perspective, which is a geometrically informed perspective that arises out of neural field theory, views the cortex as a continuous sheet.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We're not making distinctions between different areas of the cortex.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We think dynamics are dominated by propagating waves of excitation, especially these mesoscopic and macroscopic scales.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We approximate connectivity between different points of the cortex as being homogeneous and distance dependent.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we know that
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There is a strong distance dependent in connectivity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It doesn't explain everything.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So some things are missed, but we know it's certainly an important feature.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So then the question is how far we can get with this approximation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And a nice feature of this approach is that we are directly accounting for spatial and geometric effects, the physical properties of the brain, which are overlooked by the connectome approach.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And a nice practical benefit of this approach is that
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Because we approximate connectivity in a simple way, we don't actually have to measure it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We can derive our basis set simply by looking at the geometry of the brain.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so we only need a T1 weighted scan, which is very standard in MRI experiments.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So hopefully that's set the scene for thinking about different anatomical constraints on the brain and which ones we might want to prioritise.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I'll now hand over to James, who'll talk about how we went about testing these different ideas and try to understand which constraints might be more important for dynamics.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Thank you, Alex.
